body_html:
Eager should be as compatible with graph as possible, with some caveats that relying on global state as much as the graph API does is not nice, so we're trying to get rid of those types of global state. This part of the API doesn't have a good alternative yet, but it will have one soon.
…
On Tue, Jul 17, 2018 at 11:05 AM Konpat ***@***.***> wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> I now come to question the philosophy of Tensorflow core team toward the eager mode. Should it be as compatible as possible with graph mode? Which naturally requires making eager as analogous to its graph mode counterpart as possible. For example, graph mode has "graph", eager should have a kind of that too. Or, eager is more like a "glue" rather than an "exchangeable" part of the graph mode. Either way, I think "the positioning of the eager mode" should be made very clear. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#20801 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAATxX1_KBvjO2NwNiL4hg9bfbCov0SKks5uHieEgaJpZM4VP1oT> .
-- - Alex

Eager should be as compatible with graph as possible, with some caveats
that relying on global state as much as the graph API does is not nice, so
we're trying to get rid of those types of global state. This part of the
API doesn't have a good alternative yet, but it will have one soon.

 of Tensorflow core team toward the eager mode. Should it be as compatible
 as possible with graph mode? Which naturally requires making eager as
 analogous to its graph mode counterpart as possible. For example, graph
 mode has "graph", eager should have a kind of that too. Or, eager is more
 like a "glue" rather than an "exchangeable" part of the graph mode. Either
 way, I think "the positioning of the eager mode" should be made very clear.

body:
Eager should be as compatible with graph as possible, with some caveats
that relying on global state as much as the graph API does is not nice, so
we're trying to get rid of those types of global state. This part of the
API doesn't have a good alternative yet, but it will have one soon.

On Tue, Jul 17, 2018 at 11:05 AM Konpat <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> I now come to question the philosophy
> of Tensorflow core team toward the eager mode. Should it be as compatible
> as possible with graph mode? Which naturally requires making eager as
> analogous to its graph mode counterpart as possible. For example, graph
> mode has "graph", eager should have a kind of that too. Or, eager is more
> like a "glue" rather than an "exchangeable" part of the graph mode. Either
> way, I think "the positioning of the eager mode" should be made very clear.
>
> —
